following PEP8 guidelines

negative.mainPoint: The following general concepts were problematic
subPoints: it is better to use 'if-elif-else' statements, rather than 'if-if-...' for readability and speed
copy-and-pasting code introduces confusion and increases the chances of errors
the code could have been more concisely formulated
including type hinting
providing context via block comments
stating what the function does
stating what the input objects are (i.e. defined)
stating what the function returns
proving internal checks using 'if not isinstance' and a 'raise' statement
setting an optional variable to a default value of 'None'
isolating concepts well to user-defined functions (i.e. improving reusability, transferability and debugging)
It is better to use a 'raise' statement because 'assert' statements can be bypassed. Note that for development work, the use of 'assert' is okay.

neutral.mainPoint: Too complex of a user-defined functions employed
subPoints: While it is good to have used a user-defined functions, the function itself does too much. It is better to isolate concepts into different functions, and to make the functions as general-purpose as possible.

Your solution did not include user-defined functions. Defining your own function helps to isolate concepts, improves reusability, transferability and debugging. These are a major part of scientific programming.

negative.mainPoint: Your user-defined functions had the following problems
subPoints: a lack of type hinting
incorrect type hinting
no context given using docstring
no statement about what the function does
no statement about the input variables (i.e. defined)
no statement about what the function returns
no internal checks (i.e. 'if not isinstance' statements)
not setting optional objects passed to a default value of 'None'
when using 'if-elif-else' statements, the main part of the function should be nested under the else statement

When calling a function, including your user-defined functions, one should reference the parameter that has an object being passed to it. For example, 'my_function(param1=a, param2=b)' and not 'my_function(a, b)'. Doing so ensure that the values are passed to the correct parameter.
